bibl.title: Letter from Ida E. Kissinger and John R. Kissinger to James E. Peabody, June 7, 1927

div1.p: The Peabody Fund has donated a house to the Kissingers.

div1.head: Letter from Ida E. Kissinger and John R. Kissinger to James E. Peabody, June 7, 1927
div1.opener:
Andrews, Huntington County, Indiana.
June 7, 1927.
James E. Peabody,
Our Very Dear Friend:
div1.p:
Your letter of June 2nd. received on Saturday. We were very glad to hear
from you. Dear Mr. Peabody, we never can be able to thank you and our
many kind friends for what they have done for us. And, oh, it means so
much to us!

Mrs. Shaeff was over Sunday eve for about two hours. She is certainly
a wonderful woman. She explained to us that the papers were being fixed
up and all records, so everything would be straight. Yes, it is a very
pretty home, and is so nicely arranged inside, and they tell us it's a
very warm house. We certainly love it and will take lots of comfort
when we are settled in it.

I am certainly happy to know that the people in our neighborhood speak
well of us, and I am sure any place you could ask it would be the same.
They say to have good neighbors you have to be one, and we have always
made an effort to be one.

We are so sorry for Mrs. Lazear. Wesu surely ought to try to do some-
thing for her. Anything we could do would be freely done, so many of
our friends are happy over our new home. Mr. Kissinger and Robert (the
17 year old grandson of Mrs. Kissinger) were over there today cutting the
high grass and fixing so they could have a plot plowed for potatoes.
They told us it would be about two weeks before we could move, for they
intended to paper and do any repairing it needed before we could go there.

You are certainly welcome to those papers I sent you. You can keep
those pictures. We have thought always we would get a fire-proof box for
our papers, but we have never been able to. We will try to have them
secured somehow. (The papers referred to are the original yellow fever
chart, and valuable documents relating to the experiments in Cuba). The
Doctor who made out the Yellow Fever chart was Dr. Rodger, Port Ames.

Mr. Kissinger had a pleasant meeting one week ago last Saturday. The
nurse who cared for him during the experiment read of him in the paper
and came all the way here to visit Mr. Kissinger. He is Thomas Kane of
Alton, Illinois. He stayed from Saturday until Monday. They surely had
a nice visit. He had never heard from John since tha Spanish-American
War, and they visited until they were both exhausted.

Mr. Peabody, I am sending you a letter we received with a dollar in
it. How grateful we were to get it and to know the efforts that the
people were making to help us. We have received three or four letters
asking us about the stories, and saying they wanted to help, and said
their letters had been returned to them by the Postmaster, so I am send-
ing this to show you.

We certainly wish that Moran could be found. A party wrote us asking
if we knew Moran's address. How we wish we did know. We will write you
again as soon as we are settled, and if we can do anything to aid the
workers for Mrs. Lazear, we will surely do it. We thank you all dear
Dr. Gruenberg. How we wish we could thank each one individually for all
they have done for us.

closer.signed: (Mrs. John R. Kissinger, John R. Kissinger)
